titleStmt.title: Despatch from Alexander Clark to William F. Wharton, August 28, 1890

bibl.title: Despatch from Alexander Clark to William F. Wharton, August 28, 1890
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: To the Secretary of State - or Acting Sec Wm F. Wharton

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of the dispatch of the department of August 20, 1890 appersing me of my apointment as Minister Resident and Consul General at the United States at Monrovia Liberia.

In answer thereto I beg to express my acceptance of said appointment; agreeable to your request for such imformation I have to State that I was born in Washington County, Washington State of of Pennsylvania and am now a resident of Muscatine City and County State of Iowa from which latter State I have been appointed I have never resided in Liberia or any of its dependencies; I have this day Remember and sowrn to the oath of office and beg to enclose the same with this dispatch I have also executed my official bond with the people sureties and have this day forwarded the same to Hon Walter I Hayes member of congress for this district for his approved with the request that he will deliver that same to the department; awaiting the further pleasusre of the department I have the honor to remain your obedient servant

MISSED PAPERS. Subscribers will please notify us of every failure of the carriers to deliver their papers promptly. We esteem it a favor for subscribers to notify us of everyomission, as we are determined to spare no effort to secure the careful delivery of each day's paper to every subscriber.

Coming Events. W. C. T. U. annual meeting, Tuesday, Aug 26th. Muscatine county fair, Sept. 17, 18, 19. District Court convenes at Muscatine, Sept 9th. General election, Nov. 4. Old Settlers' Reunion at Wilton, Sept. 3.
Go to Cohn's for clothing. Smoke Long Havanna Filler. A pleasant smoker -- the Pointer. Read Dr. Lanoix' card on page 2 Buy Wapsie meat.

The Saturday of Des Moines prints a portrait and biography of A. Clark and calls him "the Fred. Douglass of the West." At the African M. E. COnference in Galesburg, Ill., last week, Mr. Clark, who was a delegate, was formally introduced for remarks by Dr. Derrick, of New York, the missionary secretary, and made a speech which the published report says showed that "he has the faculty of saying a great deal in a very interesting way." The conference adopted the following resultion: Resolved. That this meeting heartily endorse the appointment of Hon. Alexander Clark, our distinguished fellow-citizen, as Minister Resident and Consul-General to the Republic of Liberia, which is another evidence of President Harrison's intention to recognize the citizenship of the American people, regardless of race, color or previous condition.
Festival. The ladies of St. Mary's congregation will give a festival at Union Hall on Wednesday and Thursday evenings,

Muscatine's Diplomats. A. Clark and S. McNutt have received formal notice and returned the necessary bonds. The bond in the case of Mr Clark is $6,000 and of Mr McNutt $5,000. The former has 70 days in which to prepare himself and make the joourney to Monrovia and the latter fifty-five days to reach Maracaibo. This to date from approval of the bon. The regulations provide that the sufficiency of the bond must be endorsed by the U.S. Attorney for the district, one of the U.S. Senators from Iowa or the Congressman from this district. In this case each of the appointees forwarded his bond to Congressman Hayes for endorsement.

While Mr. McNutt's bond is a strong one and ample in every respect, Mr. Clark's is probably the strongest ever given by any one in Muscatine county, as its four signers represent considerably more than a million dollars.
